Good question. Extracting method names to constants is about the best you can do - that or persuade your masters to 
upgrade to Java 5 and JMock 2, which uses wildcard generics rather well to let you set expectations on actual methods 
rather than just method names. Come to think of it, that would bring JUnit 4 into the picture as well.

---
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Mark Levison wrote:
> 
> 
> I'm finally playing around with mocking frameworks and am struggling
> to decide between RMock 2.0 and JMock 1.2 (we're stuck at Java1.4).
> 
> I'm attracted to the clear language of the JMock interface but I'm
> just stuck on the fact that it uses strings to refer to methods.
> 
> So I'm wondering do regular users find they have problems with
> changing method names?
> 
> Cheers
> Mark Levison
